Project Description  The  Project  aims  to  reduce  poverty  for  the  inhabitants  of  the 
coastal zone of Thatta and Badin districts in Sindh Province. The 
project strategy is to help these households sustainably increase 
their incomes, their access to public services, and their capacity to 
manage the natural resource base on which they live.  
 
At  the  household  level,  demand-driven  skills  training,  links  to 
microfinance  services,  and  improved  coastal  resource 
development  (mangrove  planting,  crab  and  prawn  ponds,  and 
bivalve and seaweed rafts) will create income-generating options. 
At the community level, group organization, leadership training, 
demand-driven community-led civil works and related initiatives, 
and direct participation in the sustainable management of coastal 
natural  resources  will  support  social  capital  development  and 
better  public  service  access.  This  will  establish  the  enabling 
conditions for continuing community-driven development. At the 
institutional level, creation of a coastal zone management and 
monitoring  plan,  capacity  development  of  the  Coastal 
Development Authority (CDA), a fisheries and water quality survey 
of near-coastal waterways, and targeted capacity development of 
the districts will enhance public sector responsiveness to local 
needs. Involvement of strong national and local nongovernment 
organizations  (NGOs)  as  well  as  local  governments  will  help 
beneficiaries better understand, engage with, and build long-term 
relationships with the institutions they depend on for services and 
support.    
   
Rationale  Sindh has a coastline of approximately 350 kilometers, a major 
portion of which comprises the Indus River Delta. Significantly 
reduced flows in the lower Indus due to a long period of river 
water extraction upstream have reduced the availability of water

iv   
from the Kotri barrage and increased tidal seawater intrusion in 
the lower reaches of the river. These conditions have resulted in a 
high  level  of  environmental  degradation,  consisting  of  tidal 
saltwater intrusion, significant loss of agricultural land production, 
decline in the mangrove habitat, erosion along tidal creeks, and 
loss of inshore fish stocks. While inter-provincial water sharing 
agreements are a long-term issue requiring significant national 
attention to resolve, the effects on the downstream areas need 
immediate attention. 
 
The center of the highly fragile and rapidly changing ecosystem is 
the coastal areas of Thatta and Badin districts, consisting of eight 
talukas (subdistricts) with a population of 1.2 million. Poverty is a 
serious issue in rural Sindh, with 79% of the people in the project 
area living in under the poverty line. In addition to lack of income 
opportunities and poor access to Government services, coastal 
households  have  to  deal  with  rapidly  declining  environmental 
conditions.  
 
The  downward  spiral  of  environmental  change,  with  a  parallel 
increase  in  poverty,  isolation  and  powerlessness  under  usual 
household resource management conditions, is the fundamental 
issue in the project area. Poverty is worsening at an alarming rate, 
as salt water intrusion weakens traditional land-based livelihoods. 
With  declining  options  on  the  land,  people  increasingly  are 
exploiting coastal resources which already have been seriously 
affected by the changes in the Indus Delta.  
 
As recognized in the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper, the slow 
progress in reducing rural poverty clearly indicates the need to 
continue focusing on poverty interventions. The national priority to 
protect  the  vulnerable  and  improve  their  livelihoods—and  the 
“double jeopardy” that Sindh’s coastal rural poor face—are the 
reasons why the Project is appropriate and timely. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The overall project impact is a reduction in poverty for households 
in  Sindh  Province.  The  outcomes  are  improved,  ecologically 
sustainable income opportunities and access to services for poor 
residents in the eight coastal talukas of Thatta and Badin districts. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $40.1 million, 
including taxes and duties of $1.76 million.  
   
Financing Plan  A loan in various currencies equivalent to SDR24,237,000 ($36.0 
million equivalent) will be provided from the Asian Development 
Bank’s (ADB) Special Fund to help finance the Project. The loan 
will be for 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years, with an 
annual interest charge of 1% during the grace period and 1.5% 
thereafter, and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the 
Loan Agreement.

Implementation  The project steering committee, with the same membership as the 
Arrangements  project preparatory technical assistance oversight committee, will 
(i)  ensure  high-level  interagency  coordination  and  cooperation, 
(ii) provide policy guidance and reform support, and (iii)  facilitate 
project  implementation.  The  Project  will  establish  a  project 
management unit (PMU) within the CDA, Karachi, headed by a 
project director who will be supported by appropriate technical and 
support staff. The PMU will be responsible for overall interagency 
coordination,  project  procurement  and  financial  management, 
reporting, and monitoring and evaluation of project outputs and 
results. Two district project implementation units will be based at 
Badin  and  Thatta  for  field-level  coordination  and  facilitation  of 
implementation,  including  environmental  and  other  safeguards, 
project-related capacity building for district governments and local 
NGOs, and monitoring of gender and other social concerns.

Project Benefits and  The Project will provide direct social capital development, poverty-
Beneficiaries  reduction  mechanisms,  improved  access  to  government  and 
NGO-based  services,  and  improved  institutional  capacity  to 
sustain such services in a natural resource management context 
for an estimated 58,000 households. The poverty impact ratio, a 
means  of  estimating  the  poor  as  a  proportion  of  all  project 
beneficiaries, is 59.9%. The base case economic internal rate of 
return  (EIRR)  for  the  Project,  which  assumes  the  community 
development component is a pure cost, is estimated to be 16% (a 
net  present  value  of  PRs71.9  million,  or  $1.2  million  at  12% 
discount  rate).  This  EIRR  is  considered  within  an  acceptable 
range. For the community-managed initiatives, the link road EIRR 
is 15.38%. Project investment in mangrove planting, crab ponds, 
and shrimp ponds yields EIRRs of 27.5%, 28.3%, and 24.8%, 
respectively.  Sensitivity  analysis  indicates  that  the  Project  is 
robust with regard to changes in costs and benefits.  
 
At  the  institutional  level,  CDA,  provincial  departments,  district 
governments, and NGOs will better understand, engage with, and 
build  long-term  relationships  with  local  communities.  The 
communities will (i) increase their social capital and leadership, 
(ii) improve  their  access  to  government  services  by  increasing 
knowledge and group leverage, (iii) improve self-confidence and 
mutual  support,  and  (iv)  increase  effective  community 
management of coastal natural resources. All area households 
will have increased access to potable water, schools and clinics, 
flood safety areas, and other services on demand, as well as 
access  to  microfinance  services.  Participating  households  will 
have better income-earning options and higher incomes. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  Project risks include cyclone and storm surges, declining fresh 
water  discharge  to  the  Indus  River  Delta,  institutional 
disengagement,  sustainability  of  community  organizations,  and 
inadequate  funding  for  operation  and  maintenance  (O&M)  of 
facilities constructed under the project. To mitigate these risks, the 
Project  will  (i)  undertake  preconstruction  safeguard  reviews  to 
address disaster risk before confirming construction, as well as 
promote the construction of safety areas in the most vulnerable 
locations; (ii) facilitate the population’s continuing adjustment to an 
environment with much less fresh water; (iii) ensure the resources 
and roles of all parties implementing aspects of the Project are 
clearly delineated and agreed upon, and establish three tiers of 
continuing dialogue at the level of district project implementation 
units, PMU, and project steering committee; (iv) designate as key 
community  development  contractor  the  National  Rural  Support 
Programme, a national NGO with an endowment fund that can 
help extend community empowerment benefits beyond the project 
life; and (v) have communities provide up-front funds for O&M on 
small-scale  schemes,  and  ensure  that  O&M  for  medium-scale 
initiatives will be sustained through district Government budgets.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Sindh Coastal Community Development Project (the 
Project).1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Although Pakistan has increased spending on social services and poverty reduction to 
almost 5% of gross domestic product (GDP) as of 2006, poverty continues to be a significant 
concern. The national poverty analysis2 shows that 32.1% of the population and 40.2% of 
people in rural areas live in poverty. An additional 20.4% of the people are just above the 
poverty line, leaving them vulnerable to household, environmental, or economic shocks that 
easily could push them back into poverty. Typically, the poor have low educational levels and 
lack access to services, such as fresh water, transport, education, and health. Household 
isolation, which is accompanied by few income options, poor public service provision, and 
vulnerability to natural disasters, reinforces poverty and hopelessness for rural households, 
particularly in the project area. Women are uniquely vulnerable as they have one of the lowest 
literacy rates in Asia and lower access to paid work than men due to social restrictions.   
  
3.  The average per capita income in Sindh Province is about $450 per year. Standards of 
living for the urban educated population are significantly higher than for their rural counterparts, 
with the highest poverty level for the country in rural Sindh (52%) and the lowest in urban Sindh 
(23%). About two-thirds of rural households live on less than $1 a day. Drought is common in 
Sindh, affecting the population dependent on non-irrigated lands in particular.  
 
4.  The eight coastal talukas (subdistricts) of Thatta and Badin Districts have 48 unions, 
2,008 villages (of which 718 are registered with the Board of Revenue), and a population of 1.2 
million  people  in  175,000  households.  Although  formal  poverty  profiling  has  not  been 
undertaken  in  the  area,  secondary  data  generated  by  the  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance (TA)3 showed that 54% are in the poorest category and 79% are characterized as 
poor. In a 2004 national survey Pakistan’s poorest district was Thatta, with Badin not far 
behind.4    
 
5.  Most of the coastal population of Thatta and Badin live in rural areas, with the vast 
majority traditionally depending on agriculture and fisheries as their main livelihood. Other 
sources of income include basket and mat making, sales of bamboo and fodder collected in 
coastal open lands, net making, embroidery, small livestock rearing, and sales of labor. A 
significant proportion of the people in villages in the mangrove swamps and mudflats at the 
sea’s edge in the coastal areas depend completely on capture fisheries for their income.

6.  Poverty in coastal Sindh is caused by household isolation—from information (about 
markets, rights, and options for change); from economic opportunities; from communities; and 
from public services, including disaster protection. This isolation continues despite the area’s 
proximity to the megacity of Karachi, which is only 3 hours drive away by good road. Information 
flows are poor in areas where few can read or own radios, where institutional interactions with 
local  people  are  uncommon,  and  where  historic  socioeconomic  connections  are  weak. 
Distances between villages are long, infrastructure poor, and few community groups are active.  
  
7.  The isolation of poor coastal households from opportunities for change is an urgent and 
important issue. The solution is to focus on community, informational, and institutional links that 
would enable households to protect and sustain the natural resource base, while benefiting from 
a wider variety of income-generating options. To deepen and stabilize household benefits, and 
make poverty reduction permanent, the government of Sindh (GoS) recognizes the importance 
of providing poor villagers with essential public services. GoS also understands the importance 
of  creating  mechanisms  for  the  community  and  government  to  interact  effectively  with 
nongovernment organizations (NGO) to improve household and village conditions.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
8.  Socioeconomic Isolation and Gender Restrictions. As much as 90% of households 
in the project area live in reed shacks known as katchi abadis (one-room village house made of 
reed mats, no fixtures) with no cooking or sanitation facilities and no real protection from the 
elements. The coastal populations are a long way from medical facilities, and the pervasive 
shortage of clean water adds to their health issues. The average literacy rate for men is 47% 
and women 14%, and most children do not attend school. The coastal areas have a traditional, 
gender-based  division  of  labor.  Despite  their  significant  contribution,  women  have  weak 
bargaining positions in the household and little involvement in local resource management. 
They essentially are excluded from decision making at the household and community levels. 
Physical isolation due to the distances between roads and villages contributes to a sense of 
disempowerment for both men and women.  
 
9.  Communities  are  used  to  generating  a  certain  level  of  income  from  activities  they 
undertake in their immediate surroundings. As the resources needed for these activities erode 
or disappear, poor households use the remaining resources even more intensively because 
they have few other options. As a result, the weakening of the fragile ecosystem accelerates, 
reducing income opportunities for households, increasing risks of loss of food and health, and 
creating a sense of vulnerability and despair. The lack of sufficient government services adds to 
the sense of hopelessness. Changing these circumstances requires help. Communities and 
households need to alter their income and living paradigm—from one of isolated households to 
one of community groups that directly face their circumstances and actively manage interactions 
with  their  physical  and  institutional  environment  to  enable  improved  livelihoods  and 
sustainability. A summary of the poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 2. 
 
10.  Institutional Constraints. Government’s role is to plan, deliver, and provide upkeep for 
basic services, such as (i) physical infrastructure (roads, water supplies, power), (ii) social 
supports (health, education, welfare services), and (iii) information for joint public resources 
(government land, fisheries, forest, agriculture, and livestock). Households in the coastal zone 
have  not  received  effective  GoS  and  district  support,  as  planning,  implementation,  and 
monitoring  capacity  is  insufficient  to  facilitate  appropriate  service  provision.  The  Coastal 
Development Authority (CDA), which has a clear mandate to plan, facilitate implementation of 
and monitor all development of the coastal zone, is poised to fill this gap. Coastal area NGOs 
provide social services and draw attention to rights issues. However, their capacity is weak,

3
particularly in project planning, implementation, and financial management. The development of 
a coastal zone management plan, as well as the capacity of all players to implement the plan, is 
essential for sustainable development in the area. 
 
11.  Water. A variety of anthropogenic and natural pressures have degraded Sindh’s 350-
kilometer (km) arid coast significantly over the past 50 years. The main causes have been 
substantial reductions of Indus River discharges into the delta, increasing salinity resulting from 
poor drainage, and seawater intrusion. These changes have reduced the natural resource base, 
with the most significant impacts being on (i) the availability of fresh water for drinking and 
agriculture, (ii) mangrove forest coverage, (iii) fisheries production, and (iv) agricultural output. 
The significant and measurable declines in these areas have harmed the coastal environment 
and the vulnerable coastal communities. Availability of fresh water has become the critical 
issue, negatively affecting the productive use of human time, health, population distribution, and 
choice and productivity of crops and livestock. The sector analysis is in Appendix 3. 
 
12.  Mangrove Forests. Mangrove forests and their environmental functions are extremely 
important to the delta and coastal ecosystems, providing nursery habitats for fish, shrimp, crabs, 
and mollusks, sustainable supplies of fuel wood and fodder, and vital protection against coastal 
and tidal erosion and storms. Since 1997 however 72% of the 263,000 hectares (ha) have been 
lost to (i) over-harvesting of mangrove trees for fuel wood, fodder, and timber; (ii) grazing by 
camels and, to a lesser extent, by goats; (iii) major alterations in the fresh water and seawater 
dynamics of the lower Indus Delta, including its maritime near-shore components; (iv) reduced 
sediment loads and associated nutrients in the lower Indus River; (v) encroachment and some 
industrial pollution in Karachi District; and (vi) failure to enforce forestry regulations. Sustainable 
regeneration of mangrove forests at key sites under community management is central to the 
future sustainability of the coastal zone and its rural communities in Sindh, and potentially also 
to the more distant communities in the Indus River catchment area. 
 
13.  Fisheries. The fresh water and marine fishery resources of the onshore and near-shore 
Indus  Delta  represent  over  70%  of  Pakistan’s  fisheries  industry  and  employ  and  feed  a 
substantial number of coastal Sindh households. In 2005 the total catch of fish and shellfish in 
Pakistan exceeded 665,000 metric tons and had an export value of $129 million. While the 
export of shrimp from the Sindh coastal area generated about $100 million in 1994, the value 
has declined to less than $40 million per year in 2005. In addition to shrinking shrimp exports, 
the overall fish catch from the Arabian Sea appears to be declining. Uncontrolled foreign fishing 
vessels and the contract fishing system are adversely affecting the resources on which the 
fishery depends. The catch is not managed to produce a sustainable yield and its value is not 
maximized. The root problem is that the responsible institutions do not have the data or capacity 
to manage the resource properly. Further, mariculture options have not been explored.  
 
14.  Agriculture and Land Base. Large landholders own 70% of the remaining arable land 
in coastal Sindh. Under crop-share agreements with haris (tenant farmers), bananas, onions, 
pan leaves, rice, sugarcane, sunflower, tomatoes, wheat, and a range of minor crops are 
cultivated on this land, with low yields per ha but reasonable yields per worker. In fiscal year 
2005 the value of the major crops produced was approximately PRs1.2 billion. Poor households 
are largely laborers on these lands. Such households also make use of uncultivated areas for 
collection of fodder, bamboo, reeds, and other plants. When possible, poor households acquire 
livestock as a method of savings and income generation. As land pressure increases and 
agricultural  land  access  declines  labor  demand  also  drops,  cutting  off  a  major  source  of 
household income. Pressure on uncultivated lands also increases, with consequent negative 
impacts on income-generating activities, land cover, and livestock options.

15.  Lessons.  The  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB)  record  of  achievements  in  rural 
development  projects  is  mixed.  Evaluation  studies  from  ADB’s  Operations  Evaluation 
Department  (OED)5  and  other  ADB  implementation  experiences6  were  reviewed  for  useful 
lessons. Under a 2004 TA7 a detailed assessment of four rural development projects in Pakistan 
that began in 1990 was undertaken and these recommendations were also incorporated. Finally 
a sector synthesis of fisheries carried out by OED in 1998 as well as findings from the previous 
five fisheries projects in Pakistan was reviewed. The most fundamental lesson was that projects 
need to be simple to be effective. The Project reflects this finding. 
 
16.  The project design incorporates the following lessons: 
(i)  compact physical location for multiple inputs;  
(ii)  measures to improve the usual 2.4-year delay in startup, including methods for rapid 
setup of the project management unit (PMU) and NGO contracting;  
(iii)  identification and use of institutions with the built-in capacity to provide needed 
services to beneficiaries, as well as sufficient local knowledge to ensure locally 
suitable methods for natural resource management and community organization;  
(iv)  enabling communities to express needs and have them met in sustainable ways;  
(v)  local-level  coalition  building  of  district  and  provincial  government  offices,  NGO 
service providers, microfinance institutions, and sustainable community groups;  
(vi)  flexibility in design for pilot work in fisheries, ensuring that beneficiaries drive the 
expansion processes;  
(vii)  establishment of reliable fisheries resources statistics;  
(viii)  balance  of  civil  works  construction  with  effective  social  mobilization,  with 
beneficiaries given significant control over budgets, plans, and implementation;  
(ix)  work to strengthen local institutional capacity, particularly for districts; and  
(x)  results-based targets and rewards systems for NGOs and government institutions, 
with effective monitoring and evaluation. 
 
17.  Government’s Strategy. The Government’s program to address rural poverty is set out 
in the national Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) of January 2004, and the Sindh 
provincial PRSP of December 2003. The Sindh PRSP recognizes that the lower districts of the 
province have been particularly affected by disasters (cyclones) and natural phenomena (salt

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome 
19.  The overall project impact is a reduction in poverty for households in Sindh Province. 
The  outcomes  are  improved,  ecologically  sustainable  income  opportunities,  and  access  to 
services for poor residents in the eight coastal talukas8 of Thatta and Badin districts.  
B.   Outputs 
20.   The  outputs  include  (i)  an  environmentally  sound  coastal  zone  medium-term 
socioeconomic  development,  management,  and  conservation  plan  implemented  by  CDA; 
(ii) effective community-driven mechanisms for community planning and increasing household 
incomes; (iii) transparent and accountable community-driven mechanisms for small-scale civil 
works and public services delivery; (iv) sustainable community-managed income-generating 
mangrove stands, crab and prawn ponds, and bivalve rafts; and (v) an operational project 
management system.   
21.  The proposed Project has four components: (i) institutional strengthening, (ii) community 
development, (iii) improved coastal management, and (iv) project management. 
1.  Institutional Strengthening 
22.  CDA Capacity Building. Under this subcomponent, the Project will help CDA develop a 
comprehensive  coastal  development  plan  that  effectively  addresses  environmental,  social 
development,  economic,  and  other  concerns.  CDA  will  engage  the  GoS  and  districts, 
community  groups  and  village  organizations  of  the  coastal  zone,  businesses,  and  other 
stakeholders  in  the  process.  It  will  start  with  a  framework  under  which  the  plan  will  be 
developed. The Project will enhance the capacity of CDA to implement its mandate through 
team building of an expanded CDA staff, provision of geographic information system (GIS) 
facilities, and support for appropriate leadership and cross-institutional collaboration. CDA will 
select appropriate leadership workshops for its senior staff, with training provided in Asia where 
suitable.

2.  Community Development 
24.  Community Organization and Income Enhancement. This subcomponent will provide 
for (i) the formation of at least 1,388 community organizations in no less than 700 villages, 
(ii) participatory planning and assessment of household and community needs, (iii) training of 
households  in  income-generating  options  and  leadership,  (iv)  microsavings  and  links  to 
microcredit, and (v) graduation of groups to community citizen boards. The National Rural 
Support  Programme  (NRSP)  will  conduct  all  community  organization  work,  starting  with  a 
review of its existing program and improvements to meet the specific conditions of the coastal 
talukas.  This  will  be  consolidated  in  an  operational  manual  that  lays  out  the  project 
implementation mechanisms, and a field guide that presents the tools and mechanisms to be 
used in the social mobilization process and small-scale initiatives (para. 28). Both documents 
will be updated at least annually. 
25.  NRSP will introduce the concept of community organizations as village-based entities for 
household and community economic and social development. Village selection will be based on 
poverty levels, interest and willingness of poor households to engage in the activities of the 
Project,  and  physical  proximity  to  the  coast,  to  other  interested  villages,  and  to  proposed 
mangrove and prawn and crab pond working areas. Villagers will be encouraged to form groups 
of men or women with an average of 15 members, decide on a set of leaders, and start saving 
small amounts that are self-determined for each household. Leaders will be trained in advocacy, 
recordkeeping  and  bank  account  operations,  and  economic  options.  The  savings  will  be 
deposited into a bank account and fully accounted for to members. NRSP social organizers 
(both female if recruitment is possible; one male and one female, if not) will work with villagers 
to  complete  poverty  self-analyses,  resource  mapping  including  household  counts,  and  an 
ongoing reflection and planning process to identify, prioritize, undertake, and monitor household 
and community income-generation and public service improvement activities.  
26.  Services provided to community organization members and their households will include 
(i) training on a demand basis in income generation options, environmental management, and 
leadership  and  advocacy;  (ii)  access  to  microcredit  for  members,  as  well  as  support  to 
community organizations to interlend their savings; (iii) links between community organizations 
that enable them to form village organizations for economic development purposes; and (iv) 
connections  between  village  organizations  and  local  government  to  access  government 
resources. NRSP also may help community organizations consider and address longer-term 
rights issues, such as fisheries licensing and personal identity cards.  
27.  NRSP will provide links between community organizations and four agencies for project 
activities. First, it will facilitate connections between community organizations and the SFWD to 
enable  community  engagement  in  the  planting  and  management  of  mangrove  plantations. 
Second, NRSP will facilitate links with the SLFD for villager training in aquaculture; and for 
community management of shared fisheries resource areas, such as creeks and inland seas, as 
well as engagement in the coastal fresh and brackish water and water quality survey. Third, 
NRSP and local NGOs will facilitate links with districts for access to medium-scale infrastructure 
(para. 31). Fourth, NRSP will link community activities to CDA coastal planning, implementation, 
and monitoring arrangements under the coastal zone development plan.

28.  Small-Scale Community-Managed Initiatives. The Project will finance initiatives in 700 
villages based on community demands, with an open menu of social and economic activities 
including small-scale rural service infrastructure and capacity building. Funding (PRs700,000 
per village) will be allocated through grants, allowing community organizations in the village to 
prioritize  one  or  more  initiatives  within  this  budget.  The  budget  will  be  disclosed  to  the 
communities at the outset of the planning cycle. A short negative list will be provided to villages, 
which will include social functions and environmentally damaging activities. NRSP will manage 
the funds and the process, drawing on its experience completing more than 600 small civil 
works projects within the project districts.  
29.  Based on the budget, the community organizations with support from NRSP will develop 
a village plan, which will include detailed project proposals. The community organizations then 
will submit the plan with the supporting proposals to the village for endorsement through a 
community meeting facilitated by NRSP. The community schemes will be prioritized based on 
two main criteria. First the scheme must have (i) the potential to accommodate practical and 
strategic  gender  needs  of  women  and  girls;  (ii)  the  potential  to  benefit  the  poorer  and 
disadvantaged sections of the community; (iii) the ability to demonstrate sustainable medium- 
and longer-term impact on the reduction of existing poverty and social inequality; and (iv) not 
have the potential of adverse environmental impact. Second, the community organizations must 
provide counterpart funds totaling at least 5% of the scheme cost, of which 3% must be in cash 
to be set aside for operation and maintenance (O&M).  
30.  NRSP will carry out feasibility studies on social, technical, financial, and environmental 
aspects of the proposed initiatives based on the operations manual and field guide. Social 
organizers will work with community organizations to make sure villagers have the requisite 
skills to implement and maintain each project. The district project implementation units (DPIU) 
will ensure that the proposals do not overlap with projects already planned and in the pipeline by 
the local governments. NRSP then will advise the communities that they can proceed with an 
approved project, and provide funds in two or more tranches. The communities will undertake 
physical  implementation  with  NRSP  supervision  and  support  from  qualified  technicians  for 
financial and environmental monitoring and management. Project books in the village, which will 
be made publicly available, will record all aspects of the scheme design, construction, and 
payment. NRSP will provide documentation on each small-scale village initiative suitable to ADB 
for  loan  withdrawal  purposes,  inclusive  of  the  approved  village  plan  and  specific  project 
proposal, technical certification of work done, and expenditure receipts, where applicable. The 
community organizations will take over O&M upon completion.  
31.  Medium-Scale Local Government-Managed Initiatives. The Project will finance not 
less than 91 medium-scale rural infrastructure projects (up to PRs6 million each) on a grant 
basis to the village communities within the project area. The projects to be financed under this 
subcomponent include rural infrastructure, such as water supplies, link roads, culverts, small 
bridges,  school  buildings  on  higher  ground  for  protection  against  cyclones,  floods,  or 
earthquakes.  A  demand-driven  process  for  selection  will  be  used,  involving  applications

will be developed after intensive consultations with beneficiary communities. The project will be 
endorsed by a public meeting, documented in a project book by the applicant NGO, with

32.  The proposals must meet the following criteria: (i) potential to benefit the poorer and 
disadvantaged  sections  of  the  community,  particularly  women;  (ii)  potential  to  create  a 
sustainable medium- and long-term impact on poverty and social inequality; (iii) beneficiaries 
able to contribute 2% of the counterpart funds, in cash or in kind; and (iv) incorporation of

measures that promote transparency and accountability in project implementation. In addition, 
the NGO forwarding the proposed project should commit itself to ensuring transparency in all of

The DPIU will review and discuss the project books with the local NGO and villagers at least

3.  Improved coastal management 
36.  Mangrove Planting. This subcomponent provides for planting of not less than 3,350 ha  
clusters of mangroves at sites in the intertidal zones to provide significant disaster protection 
from  storm-induced  tidal  surges  and  episodic  cyclones.  The  plantations  will  also  improve 
substantially  the  coastal  environment,  thereby  increasing  biodiversity,  and  provide  much-
needed new habitats for juvenile commercial fish stocks. Community members who work on the 
plantations will benefit from wood and vegetation yields in these new sites, fish cultivation 
options  in  their  mangrove  areas,  and  a  partnership  with  the  government  for  sustainable 
management of mangrove resources. The mobilized communities will have an increased sense 
of ownership and commitment to the Project, which will strengthen subcomponent effectiveness. 
37.  Sites have been identified in Thatta at Keti Bander and Shah Bander, and in Badin at the 
northwest corner of the Zero Point Inland Sea. About 3,000 ha of new plantings and 350 ha of 
infill planting will be done along tidal creeks and in the intertidal zone of the dhand (swamp) 
system near Ahmad Rajo. The areas have been selected based on (i) suitability of soil and tidal 
flow  characteristics  for  maximum  environmental  enhancement,  (ii)  absence  of  significant 
pollution,  (iii)  presence  of  adjacent  coastal  rural  communities  that  can  be  mobilized  for 
mangrove management, and (iv) absence of coverage by other rehabilitation programs. Two

9
local mangrove species which have been planted successfully in the project area, Avicennia 
marina and Rhizophora mucronata, will be used for the Project. Small saplings will be planted in 
mixed-species and single-species clusters and belts 50–100 meters wide. The mangroves will 
be planted at a density of about 1,100 plants per ha, or one plant per nine square meters.  
38.  International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) will work 
closely  with  the  Sindh  Forestry  Department  and  NRSP,  starting  with  a  public  information 
campaign about the multiple benefits of mangroves. IUCN, NRSP, and the Department of 
Forests will engage communities living near the planting areas that choose to participate in 
mangrove planting and establishment. Further, IUCN will arrange for community training in 
mangrove sustainable management, and in mangrove planting and tending techniques. The 
Sindh Provincial Forest and Wildlife Department (SFWD) will manage the physical nursery 
establishment and mangrove planting processes, providing all necessary technical and logistical 
support  plus  payment  for  agreed  services.  SFWD  will  arrange  community  policing  and 
replanting activities. IUCN, with NRSP links, will provide communities with training and technical 
support on how to protect and sustainably use the mangrove areas for fodder, fuel, and fisheries 
production and sale. IUCN will use global positioning systems to mark off areas to be placed in 
the CDA GIS, monitor processes, and report on results. 
39.  Prawn and Crab Ponds, and Bivalve and Seaweed Raft Cultivation. The second 
subcomponent entails developing simple aquaculture ponds and trials of prawn, crab, bivalve, 
and seaweed cultivation methods. Households can replicate these if the technology is found 
appropriate and environmental safeguards are incorporated. Endogenous species fully adapted 
to local environmental conditions have been selected: (i) two prawn species, Penaeus indicus 
and Penaeus merguiensis; (ii) the mud crab, Scylla serrata; (iii) a local species of oyster, 
Crassostrea rivularis; (iv) the mussel, Perna viridisand; and (v) local seaweed species, Ulva. 
Enteromorpha Porphyra. Saline water shrimp ponds and crab ponds will be pilot tested.9 If the 
pilot is successful, suitable government-owned land for more ponds will be available, subject to 
advance environmental planning and regulation to avoid future pollution and environmental 
degradation. Rafts can be sited at many creeks. Private sector interest and potential financing 
from a local commercial bank10 have been confirmed. 
40.  At each of two sites, 10 ponds will be constructed—five for crabs and five for shrimp. 
The 20 trial ponds will be 20 meters by 50 meters, or about 0.1 ha each. The ponds will be dug 
deeply into sites above mean high tide level, with bunds to prevent encroachment during spring 
tides. Seawater will be supplied by a gravity-fed system relying on the ebb and flow of the twice-
daily tide. The shrimp ponds will be seeded with post-larvae from the Hawkes Bay shrimp 
hatchery or Gharo site. The crab ponds will be seeded with young crabs caught by local 
villagers in the mangrove swamps. The crabs will be fed trash fish and shrimp. The shrimp will 
feed on commercial feed pellets, or a combination of cow and poultry waste, diaminophosphate, 
molasses, and yeast. Shrimp ponds yield 1,950 kilograms (kg) per ha after 4 months, and crab 
ponds produce 4,735 kg/ha after 4 months. The market for shrimps is large, with local prices in 
the project area at PRs450–500/kg. Crabs are a valuable export with a significant market 
(PRs80/kg on pond sites), and the potential for direct seaweed exports and local sale of extracts 
is high. Harvest and marketing of the prawns and crabs will be managed carefully, taking into 
consideration a good return fairly distributed to the local communities involved in the operation. 
41.  Oysters and mussels as well as seaweed will be cultivated on a pilot scale by growing 
them on ropes attached to simple rafts. Six rafts will be sited at each of three sites (three for 
mussels and oysters, and three for seaweed) with two extra for bivalves in the most promising

C.   Special Features 
46.  Community-Driven Development Processes. The Project will develop the capacity of 
communities to undertake participatory planning and resource allocation based on a simple, 
results-oriented approach grounded in the principles of community empowerment, transparency, 
and ownership. With NRSP facilitation, communities will (i) organize themselves, (ii) decide 
what their most pressing problems are and how best to address them, (iii) mobilize a portion of 
the resources needed to deal with their issues, and (iv) manage and monitor the changes in 
their conditions. Capacity building, small- and medium-scale interventions, mangrove planting 
arrangements,  and  experimentation  in  villager  aquaculture  will  be  community-driven.  This 
process  will  empower  communities,  which  is  necessary  to  address  poverty  and  access 
problems in a sustainable manner.  
47.  Simplified  Implementation  Processes  for  Faster  Startup,  Using  Trusted  and 
Proven Partnerships. Under the Project, NRSP will implement the community organization, 
income  generation  and  small-scale  initiatives  activities.  NRSP  will  work  together  with 
Government agencies and other NGOs for mangrove planting (Coastal Forest Division, with

11
IUCN), fisheries surveying and pond and aquaculture development (Fisheries), and district 
government for medium-scale infrastructure. NRSP’s presence in the two project districts, and 
successful history of community development in 34 other districts throughout Pakistan, places it 
in a unique position to expand to the harsher coastal zone of Sindh. With its internship practice, 
NRSP is able to field additional staff in the shortest time possible and can start working in the 
project areas quickly to engage with poor households and start providing a reliable community 
presence.  IUCN’s  12  years  of  work  with  SFWD  will  also  provide  rapid  engagement  for 
mangrove and coastal zone management with project area communities. 
48.  Transparent  Anticorruption  Mechanisms  at  the  Local  Level.  Making  programs 
accountable to beneficiaries and insisting on effective public transparency of information helps 
ensure  integrity  and  success  in  small-scale  civil  works  programs.  The  integrity  measures 
introduced under the Project include (i) community-led and -validated project identification; 
(ii) transparent selection criteria and processes; (iii) participatory review and public audit of the 
schemes involving the local communities; (iv) project books that provide detailed information on 
project design, costing, implementation processes, and finances maintained in the villages to 
ensure accessibility to the beneficiaries and their communities; (v) project-related information 
disseminated on publicly accessible media, such as local radio, notice boards, and Web site; 
(vi) selection committee with representation from the community, including women, to make the 
final selection on medium-scale infrastructure to be financed under the Project; (vii) provision for 
distribution of tender documents and information from the DPIU office as well as the concerned 
line agency office; and (viii) grievance review mechanism with provision of a focal point in the 
districts for any complaints about community issues. Further details are in Appendix 5. 
49.  Gender Responsiveness. The Project has significant potential for greater gender equity

monitoring and evaluation, including gender-disaggregated data for these purposes.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic Benefits  
72.  The Project will provide four types of mechanisms with measurable impact: (i) skills 
training  and  links  to  microcredit  for  income-generation  options;  (ii)  microsavings; 
(iii) development  of  mangrove  stands  and  simple  aquaculture  options  for  household-level 
implementation;  and  (iv)  provision  of  small-scale  initiatives  and  medium-scale  community 
infrastructure. For simplicity and clarity, the final economic analysis was completed on the 
contributions of the pond and raft mariculture, as well as the returns to mangrove plantations 
and related fish production. Workers also will benefit from wood and vegetation yields in these 
new sites, fish cultivation options in their mangrove areas, and a partnership with government 
for sustainable management of the mangrove resources. The mobilized communities will have 
an increased sense of ownership and commitment, which will strengthen the subcomponent’s 
effectiveness and sustainability.  
73.  The Project will introduce shrimp, crab, bivalve, and seaweed aquaculture linked to 
protective planting of the mangroves. Aquaculture based on community ponds and rafts will 
provide livelihood opportunities, and household incomes will increase as a result of finfish, 
shrimp, and crab and bivalve sales. The benefits from mangroves include increases in fish 
stocks and fish catch, sales of firewood and fodder, and protection of land that otherwise 
probably would be lost to seawater encroachment. Additionally, these activities will likely enable 
communities to improve management of their natural resource base, enabling more diversified, 
regular, and sustainable incomes from these sources. Investment in mangrove planting and 
aquaculture yields economic internal rates of return (EIRR) of 27.5% and 24.6%, respectively.  
74.  The  base  case  EIRR  for  the  Project,  which  assumes  the  community  development 
component is a pure cost, is estimated at 16% (net present value of PRs71.9 million, or $1.2 
million at 12% discount rate). This EIRR is considered within an acceptable range. Sensitivity 
analysis indicates that the Project is modest to robust with regard to changes in costs and 
benefits. For the community-based participatory initiatives, the benefits of link roads have been 
evaluated  based  on  the  availability  of  average  daily  traffic  data  and  the  probability  that 
communities would select roads for funding. The EIRR for such roads is 15.38%. 
75.  The poverty impact of the Project is measured using a weighted average incidence of 
the poor in each of the categories of project beneficiaries as the means of estimating the poor 
as a proportion of all project beneficiaries. The resulting poverty impact ratio is estimated at 
59.9%. This supports the overall thrust of the Project, which is to reduce poverty. 
B.  Social Impacts 
76.   All communities where the community organizations operate will have increased access 
to fresh water, schools and clinics, safety areas, and other infrastructure on a demand basis. 
The  result  will  be  improved  health,  educational  opportunities,  and  market  access  for  all 
households in the affected villages, reaching far beyond the directly targeted beneficiary group. 
In addition, access to microsavings and safety areas provides a community cushion against 
disasters, and helps prevent households from having to borrow for emergencies. Thus, poor 
households are protected from labor bondage, and the physical safety of families and their 
movable assets is increased. The community organization process has a number of intangible

18  
benefits, including increasing trained leaders, improving access to government services through 
greater knowledge and group leverage, expanding community social capital, and enhancing 
self-confidence and support.  
C.  Environmental Impacts 
77.  Under ADB’s environmental classification system, the Project has been designated 
category B. An initial environmental examination (IEE) (Supplementary Appendix D) has been 
prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  environmental  assessment  and  environmental  review 
procedures. Potential negative environmental impacts from the Project are not anticipated to be 
significant. The selection criteria for subprojects exclude any sites of ecological importance, or 
subprojects identified as having significant negative impact. The environmental assessment and 
review procedure (EARP) prepared for the Project (Supplementary Appendix E) will be utilized 
to screen and evaluate proposed subprojects for approval.  
D.  Risks 
78.  A review of experience in coastal Sindh, experience with other projects, and a general 
knowledge of prevailing climatic conditions in the project area suggest the following risks:  
79.  Cyclone and Storm Surges. Unprotected initiatives in parts of the project area subject 
to storm surges have a probability of being damaged by floods in one out of every three years. 
The probability of a major disaster in the zone is 1 year out of every 30 years. To reduce these 
risks, the pre-selection safeguard review will consider carefully the likelihood of damage in any 
area. Options for protection will be discussed and implemented, including the promotion of 
safety area construction of schools in the most vulnerable areas. Disaster preparedness will be 
a core part of training for the community organization members and their communities.     
80.  Declining Fresh water Discharge to the Indus River Delta. The ongoing activities 
upstream from the delta area, including growth of Karachi and further irrigation projects, suggest 
that the amount of water flowing to the sea will be low for the foreseeable future. This will 
continue  to  have  major  environmental  impacts,  including  salt  water  intrusion  into  coastal 
aquifers,  shoreline  erosion  due  to  lack  of  sediment  deposition,  and  other  factors.  Project 
activities will facilitate the population’s adjustment to an environment with much lower availability 
of fresh water, enabling the people to cope with these changes more effectively. 
81.  Institutional Disengagement. The Project is established to help very poor households 
reduce poverty. For the process to be effective, the NGOs and Government agencies must work 
closely together, and focus on empowerment of the beneficiaries. To reduce this risk, resources 
and roles of all parties have been delineated clearly and simplified. The GoS has encouraged 
strongly collaboration well before project startup. Effective DPIUs, PMU, and PSC should help 
resolve any confusion or misunderstandings. 
82.  Sustainability  and  Operation  and  Maintenance.  To  mitigate  this  risk,  NRSP  will 
implement the key community development subcomponents, with an endowment fund that can 
help extend community empowerment benefits beyond the project life. NRSP also will assist in 
the formation of citizen community boards for longer-term operations. Community organizations 
will identify, plan, implement, and maintain the subprojects under the small-scale initiatives. For 
medium-scale community infrastructure, the Government will ensure that the O&M budget will 
be sustained. DPIU engineers will be responsible for monitoring both, with regular review by the 
PMU senior rural engineer. 
83.  None of the project components, activities, or civil works is expected to entail any land 
acquisition, conversion, donation, or restrictions of access that will trigger ADB's policy on 
Involuntary Resettlement (1995). The GoS will ensure that no project component or activity will 
entail  any  involuntary  resettlement  impacts,  or  any  permanent  or  temporary  adverse 
socioeconomic impacts arising from any land acquisition, conversion, donation, or restrictions of

access. Further, the GoS will ensure that any land utilized for the Project, whether government-
owned or otherwise, is not occupied or under use as defined by ADB's policy on Involuntary

Pakistan’s poverty analysis worka shows that about 32.1% of the national population lives in poverty. An additional

Pakistan’s rural poor are landless. Most of the poor and vulnerable non-poor, when employed, work in the informal 
sector. Thus they are less likely to have stable incomes and move out of poverty. More than half work in agriculture, 
fisheries, and forestry, and another 21% in trade and community services. The rural poor are highly vulnerable to 
changes in climatic conditions, particularly droughts and cyclones. Typically, the poor have low educational levels and 
lack of access to services, such as fresh water, transport, education, and health services. The combination of few 
income options and poor access to public service access reinforces their poverty and hopelessness. Women are 
particularly vulnerable, as they have one of the lowest literacy rates in Asia at 40% and have lower access to paid 
work than men due to social and other restrictions.   
The average per capita income in Sindh Province is about $450 per year. About two thirds of the rural population lives 
on less than $1 a day. The project districts—Thatta and Badin—were rated two of the poorest in a 2004 nationwide 
village survey.b Only 17% of the land area has fresh water. In addition to lacking fresh water, poor households in 
Sindh, and particularly in the project area, are characterized by (i) few income-generating options; (ii) low levels of 
education (47% literacy for men, 14% for women); and (iii) unmet needs for transport, education, and health services. 
Drought is common, affecting the population dependent on non-irrigated lands in particular. 
Sindh has a coastline of approximately 350 kilometers, a major portion of which comprises the Indus River Delta. The 
coastal areas of Thatta and Badin districts are highly vulnerable to natural disasters and human impact. This has 
caused continued deterioration of environmental conditions and socioeconomic circumstances. Significantly reduced 
flows in the lower Indus have reduced the availability of irrigation water from the Kotri barrage and increased tidal 
seawater intrusion in the lower reaches of the river. These conditions have resulted in a high level of environmental 
degradation, consisting of tidal saltwater intrusion, productive land loss, decline in the mangrove habitat, concomitant 
erosion along tidal creeks, and almost certainly a loss of inshore fish stocks. As a result of the water shortage and 
degradation of groundwater and surface fresh water resources, potable water sources are scarce, with severe 
implications for agriculture, livestock, human health, and income-generation options. As this continues, more people 
are driven to fishing, or collecting and gathering of wood, bamboo, or reeds for sale. This, in turn, puts additional 
pressure on the fragile landscape. 
In the project area, almost all of the 79% of households below the poverty line of $1 per day have few income-
generating opportunities, little or no access to public services, and high vulnerability to environmental conditions and 
ecosystem erosion. A multipronged effort is needed to address poverty. The poor must have improved and diversified 
options for income generation to reduce risk and increase household income. If the households engage in a focused 
effort to regenerate and improve usage of particularly saline areas their income options will expand, contributing to a 
healthier, sustainable natural resource base. These households also must have better access to public services, 
particularly fresh water, transport, sanitation, and opportunities for basic education and health services. In this way, 
they can be healthy and aware enough to exploit new income options. Finally, households must work together to 
enable more effective choices for stabilizing and sustainably exploiting the changing natural environment in which they 
live, as they depend heavily on their physical circumstances and landscape for most of their income and their 
improved safety.   
Since 2001, the Government of Pakistan has approached the multiple problems of poverty reduction much more 
aggressively. Pakistan and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) signed a poverty partnership agreement (PPA) in 
2002.  National  and  provincial  poverty  reduction  strategy  papers  have  been  prepared.  In  recent  years,  the

Overall Status and Causes of Poverty  
A socioeconomic analysis was carried out in the project area of Thatta and Badin districts to assess the expected 
socioeconomic impact of the Project. Of the 1.04 million persons in the project area, 79% live in poverty. Further, 54% 
of the populations in the eight talukas (subdistrict) were found to be extremely poor (compared with about 12% in the 
national population).  
 
The basic causes of poverty are (i) lack of access to productive resources (mainly water and land); (ii) insufficient 
public services, such as clean water, health services, education, and transport; and (iii) erosion of household 
resources and income generation options due to illness, ecosystem damage, and natural disasters. Low levels of 
education  and  social  status  also  contribute  to  poverty.  The  lack  of  sustainable  land  and  water  ecosystem 
management, social protection measures, participatory governance, entrepreneurship, and alternative livelihood 
opportunities make the landless—and women particularly—vulnerable. Poverty in these areas is correlated with (i) 
household economic characteristics, such as no or low land ownership and few employment opportunities; (ii) lack of 
access to basic services, leading to poor health, lack of education, and vulnerability of most households to natural 
hazards; and (iii) change in the environment from fresh water to brackish water systems, and a lack of training or 
ability of the population to adjust to the change and sustainably manage their natural resource base due to insufficient 
information, social support, or community engagement. 
 
Landless, small farmers, and fisherfolk identified the main problems in Thatta and Badin as a shortage of fresh water 
supply, income opportunities, and public services. The community groups’ expectations of the benefits and impacts of 
the Project are (i) improved drinking water supply; (ii) improved health facilities, including access to medicines and 
health care professionals; (iii) access to link roads between remote settlements; (iv) skills development and training, 
including materials for schools; and (v) livestock improvement. All women interviewed expected to benefit from the 
Project mainly by improved drinking water followed by health services.   
 
Economic and Social Impacts 
 
The Project will provide a wide range of alternative livelihood opportunities interwoven into a sustainable natural 
resource management process. Essential public services, such as water supplies, roads, bridges, and schools and 
training, will be provided on a demand-driven basis to complement the income-generation options. The livelihood 
opportunities will include but not be limited to simple, but important, natural resource management arrangements, 
such as mariculture and mangrove replanting. Further, certain income generation options will encourage more 
community-based mobilization of resources and more sustainable use of the ecological base on which people live. By 
widening their income options, and encouraging sustainable management of the coastal and inland areas, the Project 
will reduce poverty while also mitigating the ecological impact of sea encroachment. Group access to community-
driven public services, such as water, roads, health care, and education, will lower the poverty of services access, 
which is a significant problem in the country and the region. Access to safe areas and disaster preparedness 
arrangements through the Project also will help households ameliorate risk. 
 
The project design aims to ensure that the poor, particularly women, receive a substantial share of the benefits from 
income growth generated by the Project through increased production and employment opportunities. Mangrove 
plantings and mariculture, community mobilization, skills training and links to microcredit, and the provision of small 
grants for social services and small-scale infrastructure are the main project interventions. The Project will reinforce 
community interest in mangroves, and reward labor for tending and managing the plantings. Household incomes will 
increase and domestic nutrition will improve by developing mariculture options for village households. Households 
also  will  have  the  opportunity  to  expand  income  sources  through  skills  training  and  access  to  microcredit. 
Improvement in water supplies, increased access to health and education services, and links to public services and 
markets through roads, culverts, and bridges will help increase labor productivity and better access to both markets 
and information. Supportive institutional development work for the Coastal Development Authority in fisheries, and in 
district governments will help orient the government services framework to address poverty more actively.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.   Introduction 
1.  Poverty  is  a  central  issue  to  almost  all  of  the  coastal  rural  communities  in  Sindh 
Province, Pakistan, whether they are on the coastline or slightly further inland. Many people in 
these communities live in abject poverty. Most communities have little access to clean drinking 
water, and some communities do not have any fresh water at all. Almost all communities 
complain of lack of opportunities, poor or nonexistent health facilities, and inadequate schools 
with absent teachers. 
2.  The economy and sustainability of these rural communities are intimately bound up with 
their immediate environment. This environment consists of the mangrove swamps and creeks at 
the outer fringe of the Indus Delta and their fisheries, as well as the land above high tide level 
where subsistence agriculture, with village livestock and fish farming, is practiced. Many of the 
local communities depend almost completely on the resources in the mangrove swamps for 
their survival. Environmental impoverishment also is high due to (i) the effects of periodic 
cyclones, (ii) the long-term reduction in flow of the Indus River, (iii) salt water intrusion at the 
surface by tidal encroachment and in the subsurface water accessed by wells, and (iv) the 
general decline of the mangrove swamp ecosystem. 
3.  Sindh coastal households exist in an environment that narrowly defines their economic 
options. Human interaction with the environment can cause further damage to incomes and to 
the coastal zone, or help stabilize it and generate opportunities to earn additional income. Given 
the circumstances of the coastal communities, the key to poverty reduction is a combination of 
income  and  non-income  interventions  in  the  context  of  a  sustainable  natural  resource 
management process. Accordingly, understanding the coastal environment and its products and 
circumstances is essential to determining how to improve livelihoods for its inhabitants. The 
focus areas are mangroves, fisheries, and important plants. 
B.  Mangrove Ecosystems 
4.  The economic importance of mangroves in Pakistan largely comes from the fishery 
resource that they harbor. An estimated 80% of the fish caught in coastal waters spend at least 
part of their life cycle as fry in the mangrove creeks, or depend on the food web within the 
mangrove ecosystem. Shrimp fishery is the major fish export of mangroves, accounting for 68% 
of the $100 million of the foreign exchange the country earns from fisheries exports. The annual 
shrimp landing has reached its maximum sustainable yield of about 30,000 metric tons.1 A 
June/July ban on shrimp fishing also has been implemented.  
5.  The mangrove swamps of the Sindh coastal zone are extensive, covering 243,000 
hectares (ha) compared with 7,400 ha along the Balochistan coast.2 The zone also has large 
areas of bare mud flat. The system is intersected by large and small creeks that allow tidal 
water to move into and out of the area during the twice-daily ebb and flow of the tides. The 
mangrove swamps are made up of several indigenous species of trees that are adapted to live 
in brackish water or sea water. The main species in the area is the black mangrove Avicennia 
marina, which has aerial roots growing up out of the mud. The swamps also have less common 
species of mangrove tree, the main one on the Sindh coast being the red mangrove Rhizophora 
mucronata. This has prop roots that grow out from the main trunk and then down into the mud, 
stabilizing the plant. Both species of mangrove tree are important sediment and soil stabilizers.

months. The creeks provide a source of shrimp and fish for the local village fisherfolk working 
from small inshore boats. Bees that live in the mangroves and above the high tide level inland 
provide honey, which is a valuable marketed commodity.  
9.  Mangrove swamp ecosystems face a number of threats, as they are an exploitable 
natural resource for the rural communities along the Pakistan coast. Man-made and natural 
impacts have degraded the mangroves. These include (i) construction of dams and barrages, 
(ii) fresh water diversion for irrigation, (iii) decrease in fresh water input and sediment load, and 
(iv) increase in salinity. For example, the estimated historic fresh water flow down the Indus is 
about 150 million acre feet (MAF) per year (180 billion cubic meters). However, over the past 70 
years, water abstraction for irrigation has reduced dramatically the supply of fresh water to the 
mangrove forests. The flow reaching the Indus Delta now is less than 35 MAF (43 billion cubic 
meters), and could decline further to about 10 MAF (12 billion cubic meters) in the next three to 
five  years.  The  amount  of  silt  discharged,  which  was  about  100  million  tons  per  year,  is 
predicted to fall to 30 million tons during the same period.3 Other threats include domestic and 
industrial pollution, overgrazing by animals, overcutting of mangroves by rural communities, and 
cyclones and storms. 
10.  Sea level rise caused by global warming poses a major long-term environmental threat 
to the Sindh coastline and its mangrove swamps.4 Over the past century, the rise has been 1.1 
millimeters per year. While the predicted sea level rise of 2.00 millimeters per year will support 
mangrove growth, anything above this rate would cause a loss of mangroves. This would 
require  replanting  species  with  longer  propagules,  such  as  Rhizophora  mucronata,  and 
propagating  Avicennia  marina  on  higher  grounds,  as  is  occurring  along  the  Balochistan 
coastline. In the proposed Project, a strong case can be made for interplanting Rhizophora

11.  Mangrove plantation programs produce proven, positive environmental consequences. 
The most immediate result is a shielding of the area on the landward side of the plantations 
from monsoonal and cyclonic waves and wind. This protection becomes more pronounced as 
the  trees  increase  in  height.  Progressively,  more  noticeable  changes  are  seen  in  creek

system. Changes of sediment deposition and location of mud banks also occur. The presence 
of new developing stands of mangrove trees have a positive impact on biodiversity—more 
species of animals and plants become established in the mangrove creeks and forest. As a 
result, the food webs become more complex and more stable. The economic consequences 
involve the input of increased jobs and money into local communities. 
 
C.  Fisheries, Bivalves, and Crabs 
 
12.  Coastal rural communities largely operate the inshore and near-shore fisheries along the 
Sindh coast.5 Although these fisheries are well-established, they are almost uncontrolled and, 
hence,  unregulated.  They  consist  of  a  range  of  commercial  finfish  and  shellfish.  Rural 
communities access the fisheries by going directly into the mangrove swamp creeks, or by 
operating fishing vessels of various sizes. 
13.  Individual fisherfolk go into the mangrove areas to catch small finfish with one- or two-
man operated nets, which are used from the shore or thrown by the fisherfolk while standing in 
shallow water. Adults and male children catch crabs in the mangrove swamps by wading in to 
waist level, and then using baited fishing lines or multi-pronged rods like garden forks. Villagers 
also operate small to medium-sized fishing boats. The smallest boats are 10–15 feet long, carry 
one to four fishermen, and operate close to shore in the mangrove creeks. These boats go out 
hourly or daily. Medium-sized fishing boats range in size from about 20 feet to about 45 feet in 
length, and carry between five and 30 fishermen. They go out daily or weekly. The small and 
medium-sized fishing boats use a variety of nets, including seines operated between pairs of 
boats, drift nets, trawls, and nets pinned to the seabed to catch fish in the tidal flow. Some of the 
nets are not legal, and are confiscated on an ad hoc basis by Sindh fisheries personnel with 
police. Confiscation is risky as guns can be used. 
14.  According to a 1986 survey of fishing gear used in Pakistan,6 Sindh fisherfolk use shrimp 
trawlers and tukri (entangle gill net used for shrimp), rach (gill net used to catch small pelagic 
fish), katra (surround net used to catch small pelagic fish), jalla (cast net), gujii (small drag net), 
bhoola (tidal trap net), and others (beach seine and long lines). Based on a study of fishing nets 
in the Indus Delta, the estimated landing in 1 month by the katra net was 5,040 metric tons, 
which included 1.68 metric tons of trash fish. The estimated bhoola net monthly catch was 473.6 
metric tons of fish and 28.4 metric tons of shrimp.7

18.  An Artemia salina (brine shrimp) culture industry has the potential for development, 
which would provide an excellent source of food for larvae, juvenile, and adult stages of fish.9 
This species is easy to grow, and has been used successfully in some countries as diet for 
finfish and shellfish. It also has a market as food for aquaria species. 
19.  Marine mussels and oysters are known to be present in the mangrove swamps. Their 
young  stages  occur  naturally  as  floating  plankton  in  the  sea  water  of  the  creeks.  These 
eventually attach to solid surfaces in the mangrove swamps, such as the roots of mangroves, 
and develop to maturity. The field culture of these shellfish has significant potential, as the 
techniques are relatively simple and have been tested in other countries. Marine mussels and 
oysters are a high-value catch on the international market. 
20.  Several species of marine crab are known to grow in the mangrove areas of the Sindh 
coast. They are valuable sources of income for rural communities. Villagers collect the crabs as 
mature adults from wild populations in the mangrove creeks. Recent trials at Sandspit by the 
Centre of Excellence in Marine Biology, University of Karachi, have suggested that crab pond 
culture has high potential. Sited at the high tide level, the ponds are flushed with clean seawater 
twice a month at spring high tides. In this work, the crabs are obtained as small animals from 
the wild population and transferred to the ponds, where they can grow to a marketable size. The 
same researchers also are working on the production of seed.

content. Strong coastal winds and erratic periods of rain in the summer impose additional stress

22.  The local populations use the natural halophytic vegetation in the sabkha coastal zone

23.  The halophyte plant group at the Department of Botany, University of Karachi, has 
developed one of the more interesting potential tools for improving income generation of the 
local rural communities in these areas. This group has grown some halophytic grass species in 
experimental field trials with communities on the Balochistan coast, using plots irrigated with 
brackish water. The grass species have been tested as fodder for livestock. Animals prefer to 
eat these grass species, and put on more weight compared with control animals not fed on the 
cultivated grasses. These grass species and related ones have potential for testing on the Sindh 
coast in the coastal sabkha.   
E.  Seaweed 
24.  Seaweed grows naturally in seawater between high tide and a depth of 10 meters in the 
sea. In Pakistan, they are common along the coast,11 growing on the seabed, on rocks and 
boulders, in mangrove swamps and creeks, and in the intertidal zone. Seaweed is not cultivated 
at a small rural community level or on a commercial scale in Pakistan at this time. 
26.  Seaweed  (or  macro-algae)  and  micro-algae  are  marine  plants,  and  the  primary 
producers in marine food chains, especially in nearshore and inshore waters. Their importance 
as a source of food for a range of marine herbivores is paramount. They also contribute to food 
webs, nutrient release, and detritus in the mangrove ecosystem. Seaweed is categorized into 
three  major  groups:  green,  brown,  and  red.  All  are  present  along  the  Sindh  coastline, 
possessing potential economic importance as food, fodder, and fertilizer, as well as in the 
pharmaceutical industry. Seaweed also has great export potential.

27.  Farming of seaweed is practiced largely in five Asian countries: the People’s Republic of

includes the role of seaweed as sources of antimicrobial and antifungal agents. However, no 
programs are underway in Pakistan to develop seaweed farming. Technical expertise would be 
available from People’s Republic of China and Japan among other places.  
 
29.  Coastal zone seaweed in Sindh could be utilized in two ways to enhance the living 
standards of local rural communities. First, members of rural communities could harvest the 
natural growth of seaweed. This will require an initial field survey to establish the extent of 
seaweed cover in the mangrove creeks and at the edge of the coastal zone near such villages 
as Keti Bandar. The technology is straightforward and can be undertaken from inshore fishing 
vessels.  Information  also  might  be  available  from  fisherfolk  in  the  communities.  Second, 
seaweed-farming technology could be introduced. This will require pilot-scale studies followed 
by longer-term seaweed farming programs in the mangrove creeks and related marine waters. 
The  rural  coastal  communities  also  will  need  training.  Both  routes  potentially  could  make 
significant contributions to uplifting rural communities and generating income, especially for 
those living in or close to the shoreline and mangrove swamps. In addition, the potential for

C.   Grievance Review Mechanism 
 
10.  To enhance governance in the planning and implementation of small- and medium-scale 
initiatives, and to address key risks such as elite capture, the Project will establish a grievance 
review mechanism. This will allow the project beneficiaries and the local stakeholders within the 
project  areas  to  raise  complaints  concerning  the  planning,  construction,  operation,  or 
implementation of the small- or medium-scale interventions. This Project, therefore, will have a 
higher level of accountability to beneficiaries and interested stakeholders. Such measures also 
will allow early identification and mitigation of project implementation issues.   
 
11.  An  aggrieved  party  can  report  complaints  and  grievances  related  to  project 
implementation, even anonymously, to the NRSP social organizer or a designated person from 
the PMU. If the complaint is submitted to the NRSP social organizer, then it will be forwarded to 
the designated person in the PMU for documentation and action as appropriate.  A list of 
grievances and the status of the redress process will be placed on the project Web site and 
reported  back  to  the  complainant.  This  will  allow  the  aggrieved  party  to  track  progress  in 
redressing his or her grievances. Similar information will be posted on the community boards. In 
addition, the NRSP social organizers will report this information in regular community meetings. If 
a person is unable to address the issue, he/she should bring the matter to the attention of the 
director general of CDA, who is required to seek proper redress to grievances. If the complainant 
is not satisfied with the results, she/he may appeal to the chairman of the PSC for further 
assistance. The specific mechanism will be developed within 6 months of loan effectiveness.

Development Bank. The consultant will work with the PMU, DPIUs, and other consultant teams, 
including IUCN and NRSP, to design and commission appropriate financial management and 
reporting  systems  that  allow  harmonized  reporting.  This  will  include  budgeting,  financial 
reporting, assets registers, tracking of contractual arrangements, and subcontracting options. 
The  specialist  will  undertake  financial  management  assessments  of  SLFD  to  enable 
consideration of second generation imprest accounts for these departments. 
2.  National Consultants 
19.  Regional  Pond  Supervisor  (24  person-months).  The  regional  pond  supervisor  will 
provide ongoing support for (i) site selection, preparation, (ii) training of trainers for village pond 
and  raft  management,  (iii)  hatchery  and  rearing  arrangements,  (iv)  seeding  of  ponds, 
(v) technical monitoring, and (vi) market information. The consultant will support IUCN and 
NRSP  in  providing  training  and  environmental  monitoring  on  pond  and  raft  operations, 
respectively.   
20.  GIS Specialist (6 person-months). This specialist is to develop a GIS appropriate to the 
context  of  the  work  of  the  Coastal  Development  Authority  (CDA),  focusing  on  the  project 
objectives and areas; and transfer the operations and management of the GIS to CDA staff. The 
GIS specialist will ensure the development and operation of an effective and robust GIS system 
that is able to satisfy the main project criteria for ongoing information about the potential and 
actual changes in the environment of the project area caused by, or associated with, the project 
interventions.  
21.  Auditor (12 person-months). The consultant will provide an independent review of the 
operations of the systems of internal control and financial reporting process by (i) supervising 
the quality, (ii) examining the manner in which the project officers ensure effectiveness of 
accounting  and  financial  management  systems,  (iii)  reviewing  records  for  compliance  with 
regulatory and financial reporting requirements, and (iv) reviewing periodic financial reports.
